natural solution: We consider the separate cases by the dimensions of each type of rectangle. There are 7 of the $1 \times 1$ squares. There are 4 vertical $1 \times 2$ rectangles, and 4 horizontal $1 \times 2$ rectangles.

a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many rectangles are in this figure? Each angle is a right angle.

[asy]
unitsize(0.06inch);
draw((0,0)--(0,-10)--(10,-10)--(10,0)--cycle);
draw((5,0)--(5,-10));
draw((0,-5)--(10,-5));
draw((5,-5)--(15,-5)--(15,-15)--(5,-15)--cycle);
draw((10,-5)--(10,-15));
draw((5,-10)--(15,-10));
[/asy] The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We consider the separate cases by the dimensions of each type of rectangle. There are 7 of the $1 \times 1$ squares. There are 4 vertical $1 \times 2$ rectangles, and 4 horizontal $1 \times 2$ rectangles.
 There are also 1 each of vertical and horizontal $1 \times 3$ rectangles. And, finally, there are the two $2 \times 2$ squares. In total, there are $7 + 4 + 4 + 1 + 1 + 2 = \boxed{19}$ rectangles.
 *)

theorem 
fixes a b c d e f g h i j k l m n o p q r s :: bool
assumes h0 : "a = True"
and h1 : "b = True"
and h2 : "c = True"
and h3 : "d = True"
and h4 : "e = True"
and h5 : "f = True"
and h6 : "g = True"
and h7 : "h = True"
and h8 : "i = True"
and h9 : "j = True"
and h10 : "k = True"
and h11 : "l = True"
and h12 : "m = True"
and h13 : "n = True"
and h14 : "o = True"
and h15 : "p = True"
and h16 : "q = True"
and h17 : "r = True"
and h18 : "s = True"
shows  "card {x. x = a \<or> x = b \<or> x = c \<or> x = d \<or> x = e \<or> x = f \<or> x = g \<or> x = h \<or> x = i \<or> x = j \<or> x = k \<or> x = l \<or> x = m \<or> x = n \<or> x = o \<or> x = p \<or> x = q \<or> x = r \<or> x = s} = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If there are 19 boolean variables, all of which are true, what is the cardinality of the set that contains all these variables? The final answer is 19.
